statement.text: Type 2 endoleak management is primarily based on aneurysm sac behavior: observation for stable or decreasing sac size, intervention (typically embolization) for persistent endoleak with sac expansion >5mm or absolute diameter >60mm at 6-12 months.
statement.formal: Management Algorithm: Stable sac → Observe | Growing sac (>5mm OR >60mm absolute) at 6+ months → Intervene (embolization preferred) | Rapid growth or symptoms → Urgent intervention

explanation.intuition: The key principle is that not all Type 2 endoleaks need treatment - what matters is whether the aneurysm sac is growing. If the sac is stable or shrinking, just watch it. If it's growing significantly, then treat the endoleak to prevent rupture.
explanation.key_insight: Time is therapeutic: ~50% of Type 2 endoleaks resolve spontaneously within 6 months. The challenge is identifying the subset that will persist and cause sac expansion while avoiding unnecessary interventions in those that will resolve.
explanation.technical_details: The management paradigm shifted from treating all Type 2 endoleaks (older approach) to selective intervention based on sac behavior (current evidence-based approach). This reduces unnecessary procedures while maintaining safety.

initial_detection.immediate_action: Identify type (confirm Type 2, not Type 1 or 3)
initial_detection.reasoning: Many resolve spontaneously, low immediate rupture risk

continuation_criteria.minor_growth: <5mm growth over 6 months - continue observation with closer monitoring

relative_indications.factors: Patient fitness, initial sac size, growth rate

relative_indications.criterion: Persistent endoleak >12 months with stable sac
relative_indications.management: Controversial - some advocate intervention, others continued observation
relative_indications.evidence: No clear benefit demonstrated for stable sac

secondary_approach.indication: Failed transarterial, or no transarterial access
secondary_approach.advantages: Direct access to sac, can treat complex anatomy

tertiary_approach.approach: Laparotomy with sac exploration and vessel ligation

immediate_post_operative.reasoning: High spontaneous resolution rate in first 6 months
immediate_post_operative.exception: Symptomatic or very large expanding sac

late_developing.scenario: New Type 2 endoleak appears >2 years post-EVAR
late_developing.management: Same criteria - observe if stable, intervene if growth
late_developing.significance: Lower spontaneous resolution rate than early endoleaks

anticoagulated_patients.scenario: Patient on anticoagulation with Type 2 endoleak
anticoagulated_patients.management: Generally continue anticoagulation if indicated, closer monitoring

multiple_type_2_sources.implications: Lower spontaneous resolution rate, may need more extensive embolization

observation_safety.evidence: Multiple retrospective series, growing prospective data
observation_safety.conclusion: Safe to observe Type 2 with stable sac

absolute_contraindications: Patient unfit for any intervention (severely debilitated)
Life expectancy <6 months from other causes
relative_contraindications: Severe renal insufficiency (for contrast imaging and intervention)
precautions: Renal function - minimize contrast, hydration protocol
Access vessel disease - may limit transarterial approach

after_observation_decision.imaging: CTA every 6 months for 2 years, then annually
after_observation_decision.discontinuation: If endoleak resolves and sac stable/decreasing

sources.citation: Society for Vascular Surgery practice guidelines on the care of patients with endovascular aortic repair
Management of type II endoleaks: A systematic review and meta-analysis
Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy, 9th Edition

validation.notes: Algorithm reflects current SVS guidelines and expert consensus

learning_objectives: Apply evidence-based criteria for Type 2 endoleak management
Distinguish when to observe vs. intervene
Understand intervention options and their outcomes
pedagogical.decision_framework: Sac behavior drives decision, not just endoleak presence
clinical_pearls: Sac size is king - stable sac = observe, growing sac = intervene
6-month rule - give time for spontaneous resolution before intervention
5mm growth or 60mm absolute size are intervention triggers
Embolization is first-line intervention, surgery is last resort
Not all endoleaks need treatment - resist the urge to treat everything
common_errors: Intervening too early before allowing time for spontaneous resolution
Treating endoleak presence rather than sac behavior
Not considering patient fitness and life expectancy in decision
